Article.Abstract: Binding of a specific peptide(s) from a viral protein to major histocompatibility complex (MHC) class I molecules is a critical step in the activation of CD8(+) cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs). Once activated, CTLs can cause lethal disease in an infected host, for example, by killing virus-containing ependymal and ventricular cells in the central nervous system or viral protein-expressing beta cells in the pancreatic islets of Langerhans. Here we describe the usage of a designed (not natural) high-affinity peptide to compete with viral peptide(s)-MHC binding. This peptide blocks virus-induced CTL-mediated disease both in the CNS and in the pancreatic islets in vivo. Further, the blocking peptide aborts MHC-restricted killing of target cells by CTLs generated to three separate viruses: lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus, influenza virus, and simian virus 40.
Article.ArticleTitle: Use of a high-affinity peptide that aborts MHC-restricted cytotoxic T lymphocyte activity against multiple viruses in vitro and virus-induced immunopathologic disease in vivo.
Article.ArticleMeshHeadingsList: Acute Disease; Animals; H-2 Antigens(immunology); Histocompatibility Antigen H-2D; Lymphocytic Choriomeningitis(immunology; pathology; prevention & control); Lymphocytic choriomeningitis virus(immunology); Major Histocompatibility Complex(immunology); Mice; Mice, Inbred BALB C; Mice, Inbred C57BL; Orthomyxoviridae(immunology); Peptides(immunology); Simian virus 40(immunology); T-Lymphocytes, Cytotoxic(immunology); Viral Proteins(immunology)

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: A previously described epitope specific CTL line was used.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: An epitope specific CTL lysed target cells infected with LCMV.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Primary LCMV specific CTL cells were harvested from the spleens of mice immunized with LCMV 7 days earlier. A previously described epitope specific CTL line was used.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: An epitope specific CTL and primary CTL from LCMV immunized mice lysed target cells presenting the epitope.

Epitope.EpitopeComments: This artificial peptide was designed to bind H-2-Db with high affinity.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Primary LCMV specific CTL cells were harvested from the spleens of mice immunized with LCMV 7 days earlier.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Primary CTL from LCMV immunized mice did not lyse target cells presenting the epitope alone or as expressed by a recombinant vaccinia vector. H-2-Db restricted CTL clones specific for LCMV GP1, GP2, and NP, influenza A NP, and SV40 large T antigen epitopes also did not lyse targets presenting the corresponding epitopes.

FirstInVivoProcess.InVivoProcessType: Administration in vivo to prevent or reduce disease

AssayInformation.AssayComments: The epitope protected mice in two models of LCMV induced disease. The epitope protected mice from a lethal LCMV CTL mediated intracranial mode of disease. Additionally, the epitope protected transgenic (RIP-LCMV GP) mice, susceptible to LCMV mediated insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, from developing disease in 95% of mice studied.
The epitope alone or expressed in a recombinant vaccinia vector did not block antigen presentation to primary CTL cells from LCMV immunized mice by H-2-d APC infected with LCMV.

The epitope alone or expressed in a recombinant vaccinia vector blocked antigen presentation to several T cell clones and primary CTL cells by H-2-Db APC. The T cell clones were specific for LCMV GP1, GP2, and NP, influenza A NP, and SV40 large T antigen epitopes. The presentation of the specific epitopes as well as the recognition of naturally processed LCMV Arm were blocked.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Primary CTL from LCMV immunized mice demonstrated a low level of lysis of target cells presenting the epitope.
